headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Biden Mocks Trump Grift, Even Bannon Says "I Can't Do This Anymore"; National Archives Releases 13,000+ Documents On JFK's Assassination; Bill To Protect Pregnant Workers From Discrimination Stalled. Aired 7:30-8a ET

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: I mean --

utterances.speaker: ERROL LOUIS, CNN POLITICAL COMMENTATOR, POLITICAL ANCHOR, SPECTRUM NEWS
utterances.sentences: I know. That's right.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- what the -- what is this? Has he lost -- NFT --

utterances.speaker: JOHN AVLON, CNN SENIOR POLITICAL ANALYST
utterances.sentences: Yes, it -- it's another cheesy grift -- him trying to monetize his hardcore supporters. It shows how fundamentally unseriously he's taking this run for president and how unseriously he takes anything except himself. And even that turns into a cartoon version.This is just more nonsense. And if this is the big reveal some folks need, let's just be clear. It's not that he got bad advice, it's that he is bad advice and he did this to himself.

utterances.speaker: KAITLAN COLLINS, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Can we listen to what Steve Bannon said about it --

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: -- because I think this will kind of encapsulate the reaction from even Trump's allies.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: STEVE BANNON, FORMER TRUMP WHITE HOUSE CHIEF STRATEGIST
utterances.sentences: I can't do this anymore. He's one of the greatest presidents in history, but I've got to tell -- whoever -- what business partner enabling the comms team and anybody at Mar-a-Lago -- and I love the folks down there -- but we're at war. They ought to be fired today.You came out with something that's so important, which I still don't think gets to the heart of it. And hey, you don't have three harder cores than Cortez, Bannon, and (INAUDIBLE). (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: (Laughing).

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I mean --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Ha, ha, ha.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: -- if you've got those three criticizing you --

utterances.speaker: LOUIS
utterances.sentences: When you've lost Steve Bannon -- look, Steve Bannon has been sentenced to prison. He's supposed to spend time behind bars for defending Trump and so disrespecting or -- the charge is contempt of Congress. He refused to give any information to the January 6 committee.This is somebody who battled for Trump over and over and over again. And when he says -- you know, he sounded to me like he was just kind of thinking out loud -- I can't -- I can't keep doing this. Because this has nothing to do with any cause whatsoever -- not even winning power. Not even --

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LOUIS
utterances.sentences: -- winning the race. I mean, this is somebody who declared for president in, what, mid-November. Has he done any events? No, he has not done one single event.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: But he has put out superhero trading cards of himself --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. But everyone thought --

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: -- which is not -- which is crazy man.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- that this would be something where he would announce an event. I mean, but seriously, this is -- this is a grift, right?

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Yes, of course.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: He's raising money, once again, from people who, quite frankly, don't have a lot of money, right? And they are sending money to him.

utterances.speaker: LOUIS
utterances.sentences: Him personally, not his campaign account.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: That's a good point.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: He will fleece -- he will fleece his fans until everybody's off the stage.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So when is enough enough? When do people say I'm done?

utterances.speaker: LOUIS
utterances.sentences: Well, you know, I would suggest, by the way, while we perhaps are talking to some of these folks, maybe send the $99 to your local soup kitchen or some people who need it in this holiday season.People are -- I think are going to have to grow up at some point. I mean, Trump and Trumpism, and what he means to this country was always about how do you react to this person with the vulgarity and the obscenity, and the different things that Trump brings to the table. Are you going to accept it? Are you going to fund it? Are you going to look the other way? Or are you going to maybe just opt out, which is maybe the easiest thing to do at this point?

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: This is somebody who --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I'm your favorite president, hopefully, and I've got a fancy new announcement.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Put aside that hype.

utterances.speaker: LOUIS
utterances.sentences: Greater than George Washington.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: This ain't none of that.And when you hear Bannon say one of the greatest presidents in American history, this guy is going to be in the bottom five if he's lucky. This is a guy who tried to overturn democracy and now he's trying to grasp onto power and still has a lot of hardcore supporters. And here he's just fleecing them with trading cards of himself as a superhero. It is just -- it is another cheesy grift. That's how (INAUDIBLE) the dude is.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Are you going to buy some, Poppy?

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Are you kidding?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Wallpaper?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: That's my only addition to this segment -- are you kidding. I can't even --

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: You cannot be serious. You're the John McEnroe of this conversation.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I mean -- but I wonder what -- I do wonder what -- when you said are you kidding, I do wonder what people who live in the rest of the country, right -- all the --

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- big part -- "bringing the world home" is our tagline here.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I wonder what they think of this? I really do.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: This isn't about New York. I'm a Minnesota girl and I'm just like this is just beyond.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Well, I wonder what your family --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- is thinking, you know?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: We'll ask.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean, it's -- look, some people say it's just Trump being Trump and it's more sort of cartoon nonsense. But again, this is a time when there are serious things going on and this is a person who is fundamentally --

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: -- he's just beclowning himself again. And some of his hardcore supporters are realizing that there's no there there.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Beclowning?

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Beclowning.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Beclowning.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Beclowning.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: And I think the concern is --

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: We can conjugate that later.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: -- his campaign -- it's precisely what you said. He isn't really -- it was yesterday -- a month yesterday that he had announced he's running. They haven't planned any rallies. They haven't announced any events. That's what people were hoping this was going to be.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: An outlying of what his campaign is going to look like.

utterances.speaker: LOUIS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Even his own advisers want to see that and we're not seeing it.

utterances.speaker: LOUIS
utterances.sentences: Well, let me -- look, well, here we are five years after the fact, after he came down the escalator, still making the same mistake, thinking that there's -- that this fits somehow in the frame of normal politics.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I think we've spent -- we've wasted --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- enough time.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Yes. But yes --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: We've got to -- we've got to jump.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: -- we should be talking about the things that actually need to get done in Washington. Right now, there are people doing serious business that will help people's lives.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Let's talk about a bill --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: -- next --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: By the way --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: -- on that front.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- Biden is winning, Trump. So you better get it together.Thank you, Errol. Thank you, John.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Take care, guys.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: And CNN is live in El Paso, Texas as border officials are bracing for more of a massive surge in migrants crossing the border. Here's what they're expecting this weekend.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: ED LAVANDERA, CNN SENIOR NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: There are a number of people who are choosing not to cross just yet. They say they are waiting until next week to figure out what happens with Title 42 to figure out if they will cross. And they're doing that because they don't to risk being deported.(END VIDEO CLIP) (COMMERCIAL) (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: JAMIE GANGEL, CNN SPECIAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: What would it mean if Donald Trump was reelected president?SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER (D-NY):  I don't think it'll happen. The American people have gotten wise to him.

utterances.speaker: GANGEL
utterances.sentences: They're not --

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: It took a little while --

utterances.speaker: GANGEL
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: -- but they did.REP. NANCY PELOSI (D-CA):  I don't think that we should talk about him while we're eating.

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: (Laughing).(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Now to this fascinating story this morning. Nearly six decades after his assassination, the National Archives just released more than 13,000 documents related to JFK's assassination. The release of the previously classified documents is the second of two document dumps ordered last year by President Biden.CNN correspondent Mr. Tom Foreman has the details for us. Tom, good morning to you. What's in the documents?

utterances.speaker: TOM FOREMAN, CNN CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: A lot. This was a huge volume of documents -- 13,000. This is like 11 copies of War and Peace all being dumped at once.What's in it mainly, though, seems to be a lot of minutia -- a lot of little details about all the endless, endless leads that authorities were looking at, at this time. So there's information about how they were wiretapping the Soviet Embassy down in Mexico, and about how they were following phone calls that came in from nowhere about almost nothing. A huge, huge amount. What's also striking about this as you read through it is that there is no sign -- I say read through it. I'm nowhere getting through all these pages. It's going to take a long time. There's no sign that there is any really big revelation in here. This really is about filling in all the little gaps because remember, this is the tail end of a huge amount of information that's been released over a long period of time -- roughly five million pages overall. And I just did the math a while ago. If you wanted to read all the pages that the federal government has on the Kennedy assassination, start reading now and never stop. One page a minute and you'll be done in a little over nine years.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Oh my goodness.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Great.

utterances.speaker: FOREMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's a lot of paper.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: We'll get started now.You know, what stood out to me about this is that this is something that was an effort in the Trump administration and an effort in the Biden administration. It's kind of releasing -- there's no smoking guns in it, but it still is important for all of these documents to be out there for historians and for the archives to be able to look through what they looked at with these five million pages.

utterances.speaker: FOREMAN
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes. If you're -- if you're somebody who lives for this sort of research, I mean, this is really a treasure trove -- constantly, lots of information.One of the big questions people said is why has it taken so long to dump it. Well, when you look at it you see that this is something that the intelligence community is very sensitive about people knowing some of their methods and knowing some of the things they have done -- some of the context they've had even many, many years later which, of course, conspiracy theorists look at and say aha, that's the whole point. You don't want us to know what you are up to. This will fuel that fire as well.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Tom Foreman, what did you say? In nine years -- how long?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Nine years.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I hear you.

utterances.speaker: FOREMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes. I'll be -- I'll be busy. I'll be busy for a while.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: We'll bring you back.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Appreciate it, Tom. Thank you. Have a great weekend. We'll see you soon.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: So, Professor Zeigler, I had read a stat that two-thirds of pregnant women actually lose their discrimination cases in court, and I think that's because of what Professor Siegel was saying how this is interpreted often. How federal law is interpreted.Can you explain what a reasonable accommodation actually is? What this bill would change if you -- if it can make it through? MARY ZEIGLER, PROFESSOR OF LAW, UC DAVIS (via Webex by Cisco):  Yes. The model for the bill -- we already have the Americans With Disabilities Act and a lot of viewers are familiar with that if they have family members with disabilities. This would be kind of extending similar logic to pregnant workers, right? So, employers wouldn't have to do anything that's an undue hardship for them financially or otherwise. But accommodations that are reasonable and doable for the employer would be available for that pregnant worker. And I think what's important, too, is not just that those pregnant workers would be able to get accommodations but that requests for accommodations would no longer be serving as a basis for termination. One of the more kind of talking things that we see now is that employers will use requests for accommodation as a -- as an excuse to terminate. So we're seeing this not just that employees are losing accommodations that they need sometimes to avoid things like negative pregnancy outcomes like miscarriage, but also that employers are using that sometimes as an excuse to get rid of employees who are doing a good job at work. So this is sort of extending disability protections to pregnant workers that we think they deserve.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: What's interesting, Professor Siegel, is where the hang up seems to be -- even though this is supported by so many groups with so many different perspectives, including the U.S. Conference of Bishops, the Chamber of Commerce, et cetera -- is abortion.And I want you to listen to Republican Sen. Tillis, who blocked this from progressing, about his concern. Here he is. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) SEN. THOM TILLIS (R-NC):  I absolutely want to make sure that those sort of reasonable accommodations are accounted for. However, in its current form, this legislation before us would give federal bureaucrats at the EEOC authority to mandate that employers nationwide provide accommodations such as leave to obtain abortions. Unlike Title VII and the Americans With Disabilities Act, this legislation contains no exemptions for religious organizations. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I know this is still in the works but on the abortion concern, I wonder what your response is?

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: Well, I guess I have two responses. One, it really goes to the merits of where we stand which is, I guess I'd say, especially in the months after the Dobbs decision. It's absolutely crucial that we get this done and we find a way to get it done. And the reason that all of us got together -- that is to say on both sides of the aisle -- to emphasize this legislation is that it's critical that we find a path through.And the way in which the bill was drafted was a kind of -- it already has some language providing for exclusions along lines of abortion that was sufficient even for the U.S. Conference of Bishops.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: So I'm not going to get into the weeds, but it's already -- there's language in there.Secondly, we have the Religious Freedom Restoration Act on the books as a backstop. And thirdly, there's already some kind of negotiations in the works, the details of which I don't really -- can't know. And I would think to certain (INAUDIBLE) on the show. But I don't want people to lose sight of the prize that we can't turn everything into a debate about abortion. People who care about this issue do care about making sure that working people have the ability to hang onto their jobs if pregnant. That has to be the core issue.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: And finally to you, Professor Zeigler. This is something also echoed in this recent piece in the National Review by conservative attorney Rachel Morrison who, essentially, said the same thing that Tillis is saying. She writes, "It's almost certain related medical conditions will be interpreted to include abortion."Just a final word to address that and your concern if this doesn't pass.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes. I think it's eye-opening to a lot of people who assume that those protections were airtight, and they're not.So, thank you both for writing this and getting together with folks who disagree with you to write this for cnn.com. We appreciate it and we'll track it very closely. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: Poppy, we hope America --

utterances.speaker: ZEIGLER
utterances.sentences: Thanks for having us.

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: -- finds a way to do this together, you know? It's for moms.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: There you go. Thank you, professors -- Kaitlan.
